content.text: State two SI base units other than kilogram, metre and second
Determine the SI base units of resistivity
base units .........

A wire of cross-sectional area \(1.5 \text{mm}^2\) and length \(2.5 \text{m}\) has a resistance of \(0.030 \Omega\). Calculate the resistivity of the material of the wire in \(\text{n}\Omega \text{m}\)
resistivity = .........\(\text{n}\Omega \text{m}\)
1. State what is meant by precision
Explain why the precision in the value of the resistivity is improved by using a micrometer screw gauge rather than a metre rule to measure the diameter of the wire
Define velocity
the horizontal velocity \(v\) as it leaves the table,
the velocity just as it hits the floor,
magnitude of velocity = .........m s\(^{-1}\)
angle to the horizontal = .........\(\circ\)
the kinetic energy just as it hits the floor,
kinetic energy = .........J
the loss in gravitational potential energy as it falls from the table to the floor
loss in potential energy = .........J
A ball of mass \(0.45\mathrm{kg}\) leaves the edge of a table with a horizontal velocity \(v\), as shown in Fig. 2.1
The height of the table is \(1.25 \text{m}\). The ball travels a distance of \(1.50 \text{m}\) horizontally before hitting the floor
Air resistance is negligible
Calculate, for the ball,
Explain why the kinetic energy of the ball in **(b)(iii)** does not equal the loss of gravitational potential energy in **(b)(iv)**
The length of the wire from C to the marker for \(F = 0\) is \(3.50 \text{m}\). The diameter of the wire is \(0.38 \text{mm}\)
Use the gradient of the line in Fig. 3.2 to determine the Young modulus \(E\) of the material of the wire in TPa
The experiment is repeated with a thicker wire of the same material and length
State how the range of the force \(F\) must be changed to obtain the same range of scale readings as in Fig. 3.2
The Young modulus of the material of a wire can be determined using the apparatus shown in Fig. 3.1
One end of the wire is clamped at C and a marker is attached to the wire above a scale S. A force to extend the wire is applied by attaching masses to the other end of the wire
The reading \(X\) of the marker on the scale S is determined for different forces \(F\) applied to the end of the wire. The variation with \(X\) of \(F\) is shown in Fig. 3.2
State Newton's first law of motion
Calculate the magnitude of the velocity of B after the collision
magnitude of velocity = .........m s\({}^{-1}\)
The collision between A and B is inelastic
Explain how the collision is inelastic and still obeys the law of conservation of energy

An object A of mass \(100\mathrm{g}\) is moving in a straight line with a velocity of \(0.60\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) to the right. An object B of mass \(200\mathrm{g}\) is moving in the same straight line as object A with a velocity of \(0.80\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) to the left, as shown in Fig. 4.1
Objects A and B collide. Object A then moves with a velocity of \(0.40 \text{m s}^{-1}\) to the left
Define the frequency of a sound wave
A sound wave travels through air. Describe the motion of the air particles relative to the direction of travel of the sound wave
Use Fig. 5.1 to determine the frequency of the sound wave
frequency = .........\(Hz\)
The horn of the car sounds continuously. Describe the changes to the trace seen on the c.r.o. as the car travels at constant speed
directly towards the stationary microphone,
directly away from the stationary microphone
The sound wave emitted from the horn of a stationary car is detected with a microphone and displayed on a cathode-ray oscilloscope (c.r.o.), as shown in Fig. 5.1
The \(y\)-axis setting is \(5.0 \text{mV} \text{cm}^{-1}\)
The time-base setting is \(0.50 \text{ms} \text{cm}^{-1}\)
the part played by diffraction in the production of the fringes,
the reason why a double slit is used rather than two separate sources of light
Interference fringes may be observed using a light-emitting laser to illuminate a double slit. The double slit acts as two sources of light
Explain
A laser emitting light of a single wavelength is used to illuminate slits \(\mathsf{S}_1\) and \(\mathsf{S}_2\), as shown in Fig. 6.1

An interference pattern is observed on the screen AB. The separation of the slits is \(0.48 \text{mm}\). The slits are \(2.4 \text{m}\) from AB. The distance on the screen across 16 fringes is \(36 \text{mm}\), as illustrated in Fig. 6.2
Calculate the wavelength of the light emitted by the laser
wavelength = .........m
State and explain what is observed at P
State and explain the effect on the answer to (c)(i) if the apparatus is changed so that, separately,
1. the phase difference between the waves at \(\mathsf{D}_{1}\) and at \(\mathsf{D}_{2}\) is \(180^{\circ}\),
2. the intensity of the wave from \(\mathsf{D}_{1}\) is less than the intensity of that from \(\mathsf{D}_{2}\)
Two dippers \(\mathsf{D}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{D}_{2}\) are used to produce identical waves on the surface of water, as illustrated in Fig. 6.3
Point P is \(7.2 \text{cm}\) from \(\mathsf{D}_{1}\) and \(11.2 \text{cm}\) from \(\mathsf{D}_{2}\)
The wavelength of the waves is \(1.6 \text{cm}\). The phase difference between the waves produced at \(\mathsf{D}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{D}_{2}\) is zero
Define electromotive force (e.m.f.) of a cell
The resistance of Y is varied from 0 to 8.00 \(\Omega\)
State and explain the variation in the potential difference (p.d.) between points A and B (terminal p.d. across C). Numerical values are not required
The resistance of Y is set at \(6.00 \Omega\). The current in the circuit is \(0.180 \text{A}\)
Calculate
1. the resistance of X,
A cell C of e.m.f. \(1.50 \text{V}\) and internal resistance \(0.200 \Omega\) is connected in series with resistors X and Y, as shown in Fig. 7.1
The resistance of X is constant and the resistance of Y can be varied
Describe two differences between the decay of a nucleus that emits a \(\beta^{- }\) particle and the decay of a nucleus that emits a \(\beta^{+}\) particle
